I Have similar situation, I can program in delphi but very hesitate to lea=
rn and test in C and C++.  Understanding the delphi example is touch alread=
y, doing it again in C++ would be a disaster for me.

I have a problem that=
 has 4x14 2D matrix filled with 14  balls (14 different colors), each with =
other attributes e.g. numbers printed on it, color of font, colored dots on=
 it etc. (actually the problem is more complicated with other attributes). =
 The same ball can appear more than once, some slot may be emptied, and the=
 matrix depth is dynamic(varies and may be smaller than 14 rows) in trainin=
g sets.

This is not a lottery problem, but an analogy that is easier to un=
derstand.

The problem is kind of seek and hide of result placed in the mat=
rix, of course everyone can see the result on the matrix, but complicated t=
o pick as the matrix is partially filled with all sort of colored balls.


=
The problem is kind of seek and hide of color balls, that is result being p=
laced in the matrix with some pattern of unfilled slot, and hotspot slot th=
at everyone can see.  The first thinking is similar to tic-tac-toe and pred=
ator/prey. 

The tic-tac-toe being programmed with no training sets, I dont=
 know how to implement neural network type problem (training sets, predict =
result type problem) using existing program codes (worse, delphi version di=
d not implement tic-tac-toe example, I dont know why, thats another hurdle =
that I have to overcome).

Would appreciate very much  anyone pointing me a=
 direction.

Jimmy

> I also started off from M=
at Buckland's book, and have been working with a modified version of his im=
plementation. If you're particular about sticking with his implementation a=
nd C++ (his is a relatively simple implementation of NEAT from what I under=
stand) I can send you my code if you want (buggy work in progress).�=

> 
> It's not a simple example at all (competitive coevolution), but it wo=
uld give you some code examples and bug fixes to Mat Buckland's original im=
plementation (mine is a Linux port). Probably only useful to you for lookin=
g at the changes I made to Mr. Buckland's code, but that would be easy as m=
ost of the code is the same, and the classes retained their names from thos=
e described in his book.�
> 
> You might want to start with getting =
his minesweeper (was that it?) example application running, and try putting=
 in some of the bug fixes folks have recommended in his implementation (I t=
hink I can help find those). Once you have that working, you might want to =
try the XOR test, and perhaps pole balancing. I believe those are common ta=
sks to undertake.�
> 
> Let me know if you want any code, or have an=
y questions I might be able to help with. I'm afraid I'm far from a NEAT gu=
ru, but I don't think too many folks are working with Mat Buckland's implem=
entation now. I think that's a great book, and that chapter helped me consi=
derably in getting started working with NEAT.�
> 
> 
> -Drew
